name: Rose Cottage
description:
Mod note May not allow camping

A fantastic place to camp above Otavalo, it's hard to beat the view. There are indoor and outdoor common areas, and a place to have a campfire and grill. The kitchen is open for breakfast and dinner upon request, but is not available for use by guests. A variety of cabins and rooms can also be reserved if you don't want to camp. See website for directions.

name: Tambopaxi
description: Tambopaxi is the only lodge inside the park, and one of four places where you can camp. The other camping sites are free but offer in one case only dirty toilets and in the other two cases no infrastructure at all. The hostel offers rooms and the restaurant serves good food but at higher-than-average prices. Camping is in front of their new lodge building which was just opening for business when we arrived. At over 12,000 feet it's cold and windy, so bring plenty of warm clothes. Campfires not allowed. See website for directions.

name: Cloud Forest Hostel
description:
3 usd per person to camp in vehicle. Includes shower, kitchen, water, use of common rooms.

Price per night includes a set breakfast and dinner. Internet is available. Restaurant also sells fresh bread and lunches upon request. Hard to miss this place as you drive the Quilotoa Loop counterclockwise into Chugchilan on the right-hand side of the road.

name: Camping Los Quindes
description:
Covered campsites with light & electricity. Open air kitchen with gas cooker, fridge and freezer. Big campfire as well as personal BBQ places.
Pool, Volleyball court and ping-pong as well as a chillout area.
3x basic rooms with private bathrooms and 1x 6bed dorm.
Great for camper van etc

name: Hosteria Pircapamba
description: A cozy place with friendly staff and a great view of Alausi. The restaurant was closed while we were there, the chef was on vacation.

name: Hostal Hogar Cuencano
description: With half a dozen options on the same street, we ended up here by chance. We had a great room on the top floor with a balcony overlooking the city where we could cook our own meals. The lady who runs the hostel was incredibly friendly and helped us find parking on several occasions. There are guarded lots nearby but they are closed on Sundays. Street parking during the week is not free, you must buy a ticket at a shop nearby. Parking attendants carry cameras and know exactly how long you've been there.

name: Puyango Petrified Forest
description:
The petrified forest has a legitimate campground near the river, but it is often closed due to road construction. The places marks the informal camping at the visitor center. 


Quiet and for free. Toilets and showers open when the visitor center is open. Road is (except last 1.2 km) paved.

name: Monte Selva Hosteria
description: wifi in lobby / bathrooms / no shower / electricity / pool.  Tents not allowed.  Hosteria Duran also allows camping  $5/night.

name: Cabañas y Camping Yanuncay
description: Only $5 pp/pn. Electricity 110v/220v + Water and fast internet. Parking on grass – be careful in wet weather. Humberto and his wife are very friendly and will help you if you need any repairs. Access to toilet and hot showers in cabin or, if full, in their house. About a 20-minute walk from town. Space for tents and several motorhomes.

name: PN Cajas Visitor Center Campground
description: $4 pp/p night for sleeping in the park. Gate closes at 4:30pm but a security guard is present all night. 13,000 feet/3,880metres.  Bathrooms / near hiking and climbing.  There are other camping areas at lower entrance into park.

name: Hosteria Izhcayluma
description: Wifi / hot shower / electricity / water / english / great restaurant & bar / 2km out of town.  Owners have built an overlander specific parking lot (please see camping icon). The hostal facilities were great with hammocks, swimming pool, great views and a good restaurant.

name: Police Station
description:
Police allowed us to stay at their police station. Friendly officers!

Price:free

name: Hostal Taranza
description:
Nice owners. Facilities ok. 10 minutes to walk from downtown.

Price:10 USD

name: Parque Nacional Podocarpus
description:
Refugio of the Podocarpus Natural Parc. 
Parking for vehicles. Free camping areas. Possible to sleep in huts (paying:$3 pppn).

name: Ingapirca Ruins Parking
description:
Parking at the entrance of the ruins of Ingapirca. Toilets (very nice) opened 24h - however, there was no water during the night.

Price parking: free
Entrance to the ruins was 2$ with English guide (mandatory to have a guide) it’s quite cheap and the explanations were great.

name: Hostal Europa
description:
Ask friendly and the hotel may let you stay on the parking of the hotel. Not the most beautiful place but very central

Price:10 USD

name: Restaurant Kopal
description:
This was one of our coolest stays. The owner of the restaurant (dutch) makes really good pizza and let us stay on the parking for free! 

Price:free

name: Hotel San Carlos
description: Cheap Hotel Option in Saquisili (when you plan to visit the amazing market). For small vehicles only as the entrance is small. Price:15 USD.          Coordinates must be wrong, ad Sawuisili is way more to the north!

name: Parking Lot at Laguna Quilotoa
description:
Parking lot at Quilotoa Loop. You can stay on the parking lot. As there are several hostels nearby you may get access to bathroom facilities in one of the hostels. No facilities although toilets are available during the day. Good 4g fast !! with claro. 

Price: 2USD pp entrance fee, parking included

name: La Rinconada Campsite
description:
Campsite in the P.N. Cotopaxi. It's a new official camping area with toilet facilities & cold showers. In good weather, you have a splendid view of the volcano.
Price: $3pp (tent) camping.
$5 big bundle of firewood.

name: Parking at the entrance to the Grutas de la Paz
description:
Parking at the entrance to the caves and thermal pools. Safe & quite overnight stay close to the boarder to Colombia.

Price:free

name: Petrol Stn
description:
Typical gas station where they do not accept credit cards.
‼️The last chance have cheaper diesel or gas. In Macara are different prices for strangers, about 3 times more expensive.❗️
This is not open non-stop. They are opening at 7 am.
Clean toilets with toilet paper.
We spend here a night.

name: Petroecuador
description: Came here cycling (3 ppl) in the madafakin' rain . They let us camp in the backyard. The cafeteria is open till 10pm and opens at 6am. There's plenty of stuff (also a mini restaurant). Also: WC, good WiFi, no showers (but I suppose you could wash with bucket or so in the backyard).

name: Grahams place
description:
You will park your car above a wide, park-like area with spectacular views over Ibarra. 
Green and  concrete parking spots, shower & toilet, good wifi and use of a fully equipped kitchen (has gas hob).

email gkersy@hotmail.com
In case you don't find Grahams place - the dirt road to his place is not shown by Google Map (It IS however on maps.me! :)) - just call him 
+593 99449 4883

Look at the reviews below- one from Graham himself saying you don’t have to email, you can just arrive and make yourself at home

name: Primax Petrol Station, Ibarra
description: Petrol station. Bought Diesel. Toilets. Free

name: Below Laguna Cuicocha
description:
***Moderator Note: WARNING! Crime reported in this location! Please use caution! 

Please be aware safe secure camping and parking spot is just up the road for a small charge. 

June 14th, 2023: We would like to report a robbery attack that occurred not far from here two days ago. We believe it is crucial to inform you about what happened to us for the safety of others. The incident took place near Laguna Cuicocha at a spot where campers often spend the night. At that place, we were targeted in a robbery attempt. We had been there for a few hours when I noticed some suspicious movement in the nearby bushes. Suddenly, three individuals wearing masks and armed with metal rods and a machete attacked me. Fortunately, they did not manage to harm me physically, but their intention quickly turned towards our van where Evelin was inside. I cannot stress enough how terrifying the situation became, and it all unfolded rapidly. Evelin, upon hearing and witnessing the attack on me, bravely opened the door. Two of the assailants attempted to enter the van, but she defended herself by using a pepper spray on them, spraying right into their eyes. I somehow managed to make my way to the door and entered the van, despite the third attacker's attempt to pull me out. Fortunately, Evelin was also able to spray him with the pepper spray too, and we were able to close the door. Immediately, we started the engine and tried to flee the scene. In the process, our Starlink antenna was dragged on the road for several hundred meters. Shockingly, a pickup truck pursued us for about 20 minutes. It is important to note that this is a spot where many overlanders go to spend the night. Eventually, we returned to the previous campsite we camped before, Finca Sommerwind. Thankfully, we are both shaken but physically unharmed. We consider ourselves incredibly fortunate, as this ordeal could have had far worse consequences. It is evident that the attackers had been observing us for some time, waiting for an opportunity to strike when one of us ventured outside. If that had not occurred, they likely would have targeted us later in the night by smashing one of the windows, as indicated by the metal rods they possessed. Our initially pleasant wild camping experience quickly transformed into a horrifying event. We have included the coordinates of the location where the incident took place: 0.2926, -78.34817 Do not camp here under any circumstances.

name: Cascada De Peguche Waterfall Car Park
description: You can stay in the parking of the cascada. It is a safe place for sleeping. You pay only US$1 for the parking. There is a place were you can put you tent once your hike a little ways in. It's a very gentle path

name: Mitad Del Mundo Parking
description: Parking for Mitad Del Mundo Monument – They told us it is not possible to park here overnight anymore!

name: Town Square, Mindo
description: Parked on Town Square. Quiet overnight. No Problems. Free. Public toilets and water available.

name: Hotel Quito Parking
description: Parking next to Hotel Quito. Free when staying at the hotel. With big vehicle do not go through main entrance but side entrance at back. Hotel is lovely but expensive at $111 per night (including taxes)

name: Roadside Turnout, On Way to Papallacta
description: Turnout by restaurant on road to papallacta. Free. No Facilties.

name: Termas de Papallacta
description:
Parking in Balneario car park at Thermals. 6 USD per night. Thermals are 9 USD per person entry (multiple entry per day allowed). Some of the nicest thermals we have seen.

Amazing mountain views whilst bubbling away in the pools restaurant on site for 9$/ menu

name: Papagayo Hotel
description:
Hotel that takes overlanders. Entrance to property down realtively narrow dirt road (ok for us). Turn into gate very tight and we decided not to do it. In a smaller vehicle this would be a great place to stay.

Way too expensive!

name: Petro Commerical on Panam near Lasso
description: Free. Parking at Gas Station. Toilets available.

name: Diver’s Lodge, Puerto Ayora
description: Small relatively reasonably priced Hotel on Santa Cruz. 5 minutes walk from Charles Darwin Centre.

name: Ps Petrol Station
description: Petrol Station Camping. Toilets available. Not bad overnight. Free.

name: Pircapamba Hosteria, Alausi
description: 15 minute walk from train station along nice track. One toilet and warm shower available. Water available. Cost $10 per p / night.

name: Hosteria “San Luis”, Huizho
description:
Hosteria with big swimming pool and water slides. Toilets by pool (Not very nice). Cost $5 per person including free use of pools. Restaurant on site. Gate locked at night for bathrooms.

Recent comment 2/17 - $ 7 / person not negotiable even for the 8 year old for roadside parking ... certainly the pool is nice. So we went our way

name: Camp Aruba Hosteria
description: Camped on the gravel soccer field. Aruba is a hotel with swimming pools so we had access to the pools. Toilet was open all night and the showers were hot. WIFI in the reception and at the pool. Good restaurant. We filled out water tank here.  Price: 10 usd

name: Camp Secret Garden
description: Road up from Machachi was a bit rough and took a while. Camped in the parking lot. Fantastic location with amazing views to Cotopaxi (on clear days). Facilities was great and it is a perfect place to relax (no WIFI) and we had three meals included every day. Perfect location for the sunset is the Jacuzzi!!  Price: NA

name: Hotel Petite Auberge
description: Camped in the parking lot of the hotel, not too nice, but it has a perfect location in the city center. Toilet and shower by the reception. WIFI in the reception.  Price: 3 usd

name: In the mountains with a family
description: Good overnight place, no infrastructure, but very very quiet.     Free.  about 26 km before Oyacachi

name: Parking lot at the thermal baths
description: Good overnight place, WC available in Parking lot, tap. In the SuParking lotlement forms very quiet.     Free.     admission Thermal U $ 3.--/Person

name: Place Central, El Chaupi
description: Good overnight place, no infrastructure, quiet.     Free.  Coming from the north on the Pan right

name: Side street in Baños
description: Staying for the night in the town, in the night bearable. No infrastructure.     Free.  Across from the health center

name: Termas Jamanco,
description: Free. Two covered huts with tables and benches and place for fire (if you can find dry wood). Up muddy hill from Termales Jamanco. You will see blue sign that says Sr. Turista. No bathroom facilities (but there are showers, wi-fi, toilets and restaurant at hot springs which are open from 6am to 7pm and cost $4 per person to use pools).

name: Parquero Hosteria Hakuna Matata, Archidona
description: Idyllic staying for the night at the Rio. No infrastructure, quiet.     U $ 5./Night      We have posted an interesting day trip at the Hosteria U $ 55.--/Person  Turn of the ring road just after the bridge turn right into large gravel. To the parking lot, there are about 4 km from the main road;

name: Hosteria Salango, Islamar
description:
Wonderful campground directly on a rock overlooking the bay in two directions. Short path to the beach about 10 min. and to Salango. Electricity and Wifi available (only around the owner's house). Toilet with shower. $6 US per person per night 
--
wunderbarer Campingplatz direkt auf einem Felsen mit Blick auf die Bucht.Kleiner Weg zum Strand ca. 10 min. Strom und Wifi vorhanden. Restaurant und WC mit Dusche. 15 US pro Nacht.

name: Bosque Protector Cerro Blanco, Guayaquil
description: Good overnight place in the forest. Showers, toilets, available. Quiet. We have had a ton of mosquitoes!  $5 per vehicle (any size) per night. $4 per person per night.  16 km before Guayaguil. Coming from the south, so you have to make a Retorno on the Panamericana to get to the campground

name: Parque Central Alausi
description: Good overnight place, no infrastructure, quiet at night.     Free  Drive past the station, turn right on Parque Central High

name: Parking lot in the village
description:
Parking in front of the museum / Gemiendehaus. quiet. No infrastructure.     Free  At the visitor center, it was for us to be inclined

Toilets at Visitor Center just down the road back toward the village.

name: Finca Sommerwind
description:
Very good place to spend a few days relaxing.  Hans, the owner is super friendly and helps a lot with lots of tips.

There are  several big grass lots to camp or park with 110volts and 220volts.

6 Dollars per person per night: Hot showers, potable water, electricity, spotty WIFI included in price. 

Washing machine is 3 Dollars per load. 

They have long term parking in case you want to go home or visit Galapagos (1 Dollar per day). 

Excellent BREAD !!!!  Basic products for cooking can be purchased in the kiosk, such as beer, milk, homemade bread etc. 

Saturday and Sunday  the Cafe-Sommerwind is open with breakfast, lunch and cakes. 

Only disadvantage: lots of mosquitos and small insects that bite badly !! The race track for cars and motorbikes is 100m away! so could be some training noices very loud!!

name: Zaruma
description:
On the plaza in front of the church, municipality, police and the icecream shop.

call Tourist Information +59396 756 5248 by WhatsApp so they can find you a place to park and take you to places of interest

name: Casa Shangrila
description: Camped in the lovely gardens of our Dutch friend Jeroen who owns this nice little place just 200 meters out of the busy tourist beach town of Cañoa.

name: Refugio De Vida Silvestre Pasochoa
description:
Parking at the entrance of the park. Check-in with the rangers. Toilets are clean and open all night. From the turnoff from the highway you'll have to drive up a bumpy rather narrow  road with not much room to manoever. Wide vehicles better watch out for branches. Great possibilities to hike on clearly marked trails. Free parking and free entrance. There is a tent camping area about 100 meters from the parking lot that is not accessible by vehicle. Pets are not allowed in the park, but no problem in the parking lot.
you can climb Pasochoa from here, however it's a 12k, 1200m climb, one way!
H+ reception with Movistar. Free (National Park)

name: Posada De Tigua
description: Parking in the small lot of a hostal. Hot showers and toilets from the hostal can be used. There is a heated community room :-) Nice owners. 5 Dollars per Person. Coming from Latacunga, turn right at the biiig black-and-white rock marked "Posada de Tigua". Good breakfast.

name: Visitor Center Chimborazo. Park Entrance
description:
Parking lot (not very flat, but there are rocks to level your vehicle) next to the visitor center at Chimborazo National Park. The entrance to the park gets closed at 2 pm. No motorbikes and pets allowed. Free entrance and free parking. Altitude: 4400 meters. If you follow the road within the park boundaries up for another 8 kilometers, there is another parking next to the first refugio at 4800 meters (you have to ask for permission to camp up there at the entrance!).
You can camp in the entrances of the shops. Good wind protection. Water tap (details see comments below).
Zero cell reception (Claro).

name: Hosteria Estacion Del Sol
description: Parking in a flat lot of a hosteria near the pool area. Swimmingpool, ccold showers, bathrooms, wifi. Ok place to spend a night driving from the jungle to cuenca. Quiet after 8 o'clock. Weekends might be busier. 4$ per person.

name: Estacionamiento Publico Colon
description:
Giant parking lot in Quito. 
Close to Plaza Foch, THE Hostel and Party Zone in Quito

name: Parque Carolina
description: Great and safe place to stay, near the police station. beautiful park near the bus station, many restaurants and shops. Toilets are closed overnight and we didn't find a shower. nevertheless highly recommended. the hour costs 0.50 US$.

name: Laguna De Limpiopungo
description:
ADMIN NOTE: No overnight camping allowed, please respect the wishes of the locals. 

Amazing views of the volcano from this parking lot. We just parked here all day and enjoyed the ever-changing view out our back window. Camping is prohibited due to the birds in the lake area.

name: El Caspi - Main entrance to P.N. Cotopaxi
description: Large parking lot to camp with toilets. The entrance gates close at 3 pm (although access to camp ground until 5pm), so if you arrive late you can spend the night here. The restaurant closed around 5 or 6 pm. From the lot you have a great vista on volcano Cotopaxi (but it is usually clouded until night arrives). It gets cold at night. Note: motorbikes and pets are not allowed to enter the park!

name: Lago Mojanda
description: Beautiful mountain top lake. It is a 16km, 1200M climb from Otavalo. The cobble stone road in is a little rough in places. At the lake there are several spots to choose from. Our guide book (2010) said there is a history of robberies at the lake but we barely saw a soul. Quite and tranquil at 3700M.

name: Stray Dog Brewpub
description: Really good burgers, but the beer fell flat - literally. We would still go again though... and just order a Pilsener instead. Be aware they charge 12% tax, for something ?? And then if you pay with card it's another 12%...

name: Punta Piedrero Eco lodge Hosteria
description: Space for about 4 truck campers in parking area.  $5 per person (#edit 05/2017 $8 pp tent). Pet friendly. Tent camping also possible. Across the street from the beach and 5 minute walk to grocery/shops. Toilets. Showers. Wifi. Shared kitchen (no pots or pans) and common area with Hammocks and tables. Expensive breakfast $4.

name: Los Arrayanes Restaurante Y Hospedaje
description: A little hotel/restaurant just off the road. They didn't charge us to camp for a night so we offered to eat in the restaurant.  Beautiful grounds with lots of flowers. Tent campers, there is a beautiful space behind the hotel where you could pitch your tent.

name: Fisherman Free Beach camp
description: Parked in dirt area next to beach. Near small fishing huts, off road. Very secluded, fisherman did not seem to mind us here.

name: Tecnolavado
description: We did 6 loads of laundry here for $13.20.

name: Volcano Dunes
description: GPS is entrance to several spots where one can tuck into the dunes, approx. 3km off main road to get to them. When clear, great views of the volcano. When we arrived, there wasn't much wind and we thought we tucked in well next to a dune to block any wind but it shifted and was incredibly windy throughout the night.

name: Puerto Cayo Beach - South End
description: Public beach camping on the south side of the town beach, accessed by the fishing boats and drive down to the far end. There is a sign indicating camping in front of a few vacation homes and a vacant hotel. Quite and peaceful...

name: Forum Hotel
description: If you don't feel like camping in the outskirts of town and want give yourself a treat this hotel offers everything you need. Very nice and located in the old town. Rooms are elegant and comfy. There are several options, we chose the superior room for USD 70 incl breakfast. Secure parking is available at the hat factory of the owner (taxi drive, the hotel pais).

name: Hotel Los Arrozales
description: Clean, safe, and friendly hotel in a border town for $20/night per person. A double costs $40. Parking garage (secure), TV/remote, warm/hot water, and simple breakfast included.

name: Hospedaje Monterrico
description: Clean and comfortable at 40 Sol / night.  Secured parking with night security guard, TV/remote, warm/hot water, and 110V electrical outlets.  Conveniently located near the main highway in Olmos and a 5 minute walk to the central plaza.

name: Laguna Llaviucu, P.N. Cajas
description: Camping on gravel parking lot, at nearby visitor center there are toilets and a water hose. No other facilities. We paid 4US$ pP/night, this is the normal overnight camping fee everyone has to pay. Day use is free of charge. Very quiet at night. There was a big camper truck, so big rigs can make it to here, but the street is narrow and the bridges have a height restriction of 3.8 meter.

name: Galapagos Islanders
description: Respected your operator with day trips to Punta Pitt ($120/person) and Kicker Rock ($80/person). Also rents snorkel gear and kayaks.

name: Hostel San Francisco
description: Nice hostel right on the malecon. Our room was $25 a night.

name: Isabela Dive Center
description:
We booked a snorkel tour to Los Tuneles for $70 per person here which included a wet suit and equipment. Very friendly and helpful. 

Update April 2017: now $110-130 per person

name: Brisas Del Mar
description: We got a private room here for two for $30 per night. Clean rooms and the beds were ok on the comfort scale. Nice owner and an area for hanging out in hammocks.

name: Costa Del Pacifico
description: Bargained down to $25 per person per night. Clean rooms and hot water.

name: ENI Gas
description:
There  a huge Propane filling station just at the north entrance of Ibarra, but barely to be seen from the highway. They can fill US type bottles. 
Coming from north make a sharp right turn at the first traffic light.
Talk to the guards and they call someone to assist you.
Open: Mo - Fr. 8:00 - 18:00.
US$10 per bottle.
Btw. Nearby is Finca Sommerwind, a great place to relax.
 .

name: Mirador Parking Lot
description: Very close to road, so noisy and not very private, but good place to adjust to altitude before Cajas. Free.

name: El Pedregal Azteca
description:
Still thinking about all the amazing food back in Mexico?  El Pedregal Azteca has a fix priced lunch for about $6 that brought back all the flavors and memories of Mexico for us.  Highly recommended.

Adress: Toral 8-60

name: Hostal La Guayunga
description: Tight parking in the courtyard with their school vans. Only room for one medium sized rig (Vanagon). We paid $15 to sleep in our vehicle. A private room cost $27 plus $5 for parking. There is a rooftop restaurant/patio with a great view of the historic part of the city. Very friendly staff.

name: The Black Sheep Inn
description: a lovely ecolodge located near Quilotoa Lake in the heart of the Andes Cordillerra mountain range. spectacular scenery and plenty of activity options. The manager Edmundo and his staff are very welcoming and helpful to help your organize your adventures in the area. Don't miss Edmundo's famous Sky Walk Trail. Excellent vegetarian cuisine. sauna is 15 dollars and hot tub, amazing yoga studio. Composting Toilets with an Andean View! And much more. check out their website for more info. Only room for 1 (or maybe 2 small cars) car. "Highly recommended" The parking was not level but there was a stack of wood blocks that we used to get sort of level. Nice bathroom, hot shower and a frisbee golf course for $5 per person.

name: Paradero Sombre y Sol Playa La Union
description: Campground with on-site restaurant, toilets, cold shower. No further services. Nice place, right by the river for a good swim. Might be quite busy on weekends.

name: Parking for Podocarpus National Park
description: Nice and flat place to camp at the end of the road (and start of the trail). Free, no services. The road here is unpaved, but not very rough (may be after heavy rains).

name: Gas station
description: The only camper friendly gas-station in Loja. Just big enough, flat, and not all gas stations allow you to stay overnight in Loja

name: Malecon Coca
description: Free parking on a little spot near the waterfront. Lot of construction going on around. But very quiet at night.  Toilets in the next door mall. Wifi at the mall ask for access from the guards.

name: El Auca Route
description: Grassy patch along the road, asked permission and we were told we could use the well with drinking water.

name: Atahualpa Hotel Chone
description: We have some mechanical issues so we spend the night in Chone. The hotel is very very uggly and expensive. 44 us for two. Breakfast included. Come only if you must.

name: Pop House
description: 16 usd for a private room with private bathroom, free wifi, for two person. Very nice place, lots of art, cool people and parking. Its not in front the beach but its perfect if you dont want the loud music and the bussy streets of montañita. Free parking. Lots of camping sites in the sorrounded area with full amenities.

name: Paute Climbing Camp Spot
description: Free just on the side of the road next to a little stream. The trail to the crag is just down the road.

name: Cigale Hostel
description: 26 usd per two in private room with private bath.

name: Finca Gloria
description: $6 per a vehicle with electricity. Very large property. Busy on weekends but the property is so large you will always have a place to park. We are the first travelers the owner has had stay here and he said they would be happy to welcome more. Also offered secure parking on property when visiting Galápagos Islands.

name: Mompiche Beach
description: Parked next to the fishing boats and infront of a camping place which has showers and bathrooms for 50 cents. There is room for 2-3 cars to park there and is just in front of the beach. Very friendly locals and relaxed hippie town

name: Las Tunas Beach
description: Free beach parking beetween Jimmy restaurant and  Wipeout Restaurant, good food there wifi, shower and restrooms. There is a sign that says no camping on the beach, so no tents allowed but its ok for a camper or van.

name: Arco Iris Termales at Chachimbiro
description: Parked in gravel parking lot of Termales. Free with price of admission $7 pp. Toilets available at parking lot, showers in termales area. Stays open until 2 am, so It may be noisy late on weekends. It was pretty quiet the night we were here after about 10pm.

name: Playa Escondida
description: This is paradise! Beatiful place, you camp just few steps from the beach with amazing view. Electricity, showers, bathrooms, wifi and electricity. USD7 pp

name: Punta Prieta
description: Great place on a cliff that has tons of great views. Swimming pool Jacuzzi (although empty when I was there) paths to the beach with hammocks and bungalows. He has internet but Wi-Fi wasn't working but will let you use his computer. I ate Langostinos at the restaurant(best I've had yet) and didn't charge so stay. Wow.

name: Free camp on a small sandy road
description:
- free
- we did not manage to find a place where we wouldn't be visible from the road, this was the best we could do
- pretty far from the main road, a dirt track leads here
- some cover by low bushes
- no facilities
- three lamas

name: Restaurant El Capo
description:
- we tried to get to Pequeno Paraiso, but the gate was closed at 7:30 pm and nobody answered the bell
- so we camped next to a small restaurant run by a very nice Cuban couple
- they let us use their shower (hot water), offered tea and we chatted the whole evening
- price: "pay as much as you want", or have dinner

name: Puerto Lopez beach
description:
At the edge of the town
- free
- no services
- the beach is rather busy in the evening and in the morning
- quiet at night 
place for camping in a shelter

name: Behind a church
description:
- free
- we struggled to find any boondocking spots on the way here from Cuenca, we settled behind a little church after dark

name: Peru border crossing
description: No man’s land at the border is quiet, at times. Restaurant and store to get stuff, and a bathroom ( behind Aduana). There is also the river to check out. Nothing on the street after dark except kids and dogs, can’t be all bad. Music from somewhere after 8.

name: El Quetzal
description: Best breakfast in a long time!  Also took their amazing chocolate tour and got to taste their super delicious brownies'. Can't say enough wonderful words about this place!  Wish we could stay for dinner!

name: Plaza Central Chimbo
description: Free overnight parking right on the beautiful plaza in the cool mountain pueblo Chimbo. People are nice, it is level, and several restaurants bbq cuy from Thurs-Friday. Pretty quiet and safe overnight. No facilities, but several restaurants and a large gas station around town.

name: Chimborazo Refugio #1
description: Large flat area near Refugio #1. Free to camp overnight. good restrooms in the refugio, no others.   Very cold at night. It snowed a bit while we were here. Elevation 4860m. Signs say no pets allowed, so we hid our three dogs in the back and didnt tell them.

name: Streetside in Salinas
description: Level spot on a quiet street in a very non-level pueblo. Free. No facilities. There are restaurants and hostals nearby.

name: Backpacker Great Hostel
description: A great hostel right in the town of Banos run by very friendly Argentinians. There is a level grassy parking area with room for several vehicles and tents. 10.- for a dorm, 6.- pp for camping, both including breakfast - and free dinner from Mon to Wed ! (sign-up for dinner on FB until 7pm) They have a few friendly dogs and cats, pet friendly. The entrance is kind of narrow and a tight turn, so big rigs may have a problem getting in, low clearance vehicles might scratch, no height restrictions. Spotty wifi.

name: Guamote Plaza Central
description: Safe, quiet, level, free next to the main plaza in the small pueblo of Guamote. Thursday is market day here so Wed night may not be a good idea. No facilities.

name: Dispen Gas Station
description: Parking at gas station with other truckers.  Street noise dies down a 10 and starts up at 6:30 bathroom/shower open all night. FREE

name: Misahualli Town Square
description: Parked in the Centro gets quiet after 10:00 public bathrooms and shower available. Monkeys didn't mess with my truck!

name: Cuello De Luna
description:
Hotel located 1.5km from the entrance of Cotopaxi National Park on the oposite side of Panamerican Route. The have a large area for tents, campervans and trailers with showers (hot water) and toilets. 

*Price 7 USD per person. Restaurant.

name: Hostal Monte Real
description: Good deal, close to the main square, parking lot available.

name: Market Hall Salinas
description:
Behind the green market hall on the left hand side when entering the town. We asked the police where to park and were shown that spot. Flat and quiet, no facilities except a water tap which seems to be good drinking water (we have a filter !!!!). The Tourist Information told us to park at Hotel Refugio which according to the owner would be possible if there are no other guests using the small parking lot. 
Be aware Tuesday is market day and therefore the spot behind the hall should be avoided.

name: Canoa Parqueo
description:
Gated Parking area with poorly maintained bathrooms and showers. The owners live beside the parking area and drink on weekends and holidays. Secure and safe if elsewhere is full.
5USD/n

name: Casa Condor
description: This place looks a bit like a community center/school at first sight. Maybe that's what it is. They have a few acceptably nice rooms with heater, warm blankets, and with separate bathrooms in a little building.  Single Room is now 18$. They also have a communal kitchen in the larger building. Next to it they sell nice hand-knitted hats for $5. The friendly woman living right across in the tiny huts, can let you in if you arrive after 5pm like we did. She told us her son usually runs it. Supposedly sleeping in the car would be free, but it was freezing. This location has a fantastic view of Chimborazo in the evening (if the weather is good). It's still quite high up and we had a hard time sleeping, but it's a nice place all in all.

name: Quesera Él Salinerito
description: Asked someone if we could camp here and he said of course and directed us to park behind the facility.  Super quiet and scenic location (sorry for the fog in the photos, but the view of town was dazzling last night).  Toilets available.  Lots of activity in the morning as many locals bring their fresh cow milk down to be made into cheese.  Oh and the cheese here is amazing!  We highly recommend the Emmenthal, but everything that we tasted was delicious!  Free camping.

name: Hostal Las Margaritas
description: A just one block from main square, pool, cheap and clean. Including breakfast.

name: Hostal Oasis
description: Oasis Hotel - 18 US for single person in private room with attached bath. Quieter part of town about ten minutes walking from plaza. Fast wifi, clean, HOT water and towels included. Basic kitchen and communal area. Parking in gated garden very secure. Space for two cars and several Motos. If you want to camp in your vehicle at Oasis II, arrange it here.

name: La Posada Del Arte
description: This is also a hotel, but we just came here for a late lunch.  Everything on the menu looked fabulous and the prices were reasonable for what you get.  We ordered 2 vegetarian dishes -- the Paella Andina and the Platenos Aztecs -- and one order of the Mexican beef tacos.   All tasted amazing!  We are not quick to rave about food, but the food here is worth a trip.  We only wish we could sample it all!

name: Pull-out With Views
description: Perfect place to camp and enjoy the ever-changing views of Volcán Chimborazo.  Could be a bit windy.  Free.

name: El Angel Nature Reserve - Lagunas De Voladero
description: Free camping in parking lot next to lodge. Eventually they will have rooms for guests, but not yet. 15 km of rough gravel road to get here, but relaxing and beautiful views. 2.5 km trail leaves from parking lot.

name: Otavalo Craft Market
description: Large parking lot nearby. Market is open everyday 9-4, but supposed to be really busy (and expensive) on Saturdays.

name: Mundo Car-BIOCANIC
description:
The real gps location is this one, they moved eight months ago. Great staff, very profesional and kind. They fix our ventiladores, breaks and water system.
Repaired our tail pipe. Speaks some English!

name: Plaza de Tripas - veggie options too!
description:
I went here on advice of a local I met and food was really good so I thought I would add it to iOverlander but... It already was hahaha
Good food, price is still between 2.50 and 4 usd
There were only locals when I was there.
There's also a small park with installations for kids

name: Airport Parking "San Jose"
description:
Closer parking than the VIP one down the street which has upped his prices to US$10 per night. No reduction even for two full weeks. GREEDY!.. US$5 per night at SanJose. 
Nice people. 
Immaculate bathroom on the premises. 
Free shuttle to and from the airport
WiFi now available.
Room for two or three BIG rigs and plenty of room for smaller vehicles

Restaurant nearby
Nice atmosphere
NOTE this is a parking area close to the airport and ideal for trips to Galapagos so not really an established campground - BUT has all the facilities you would need so I'll leave the site classification as it is.

PS They have their own small soccer field right next to the parking area and there would be plenty of space behind the goals for those needing to pitch a tent.

Owner is willing to negotiate a much reduced price for leaving vehicles there for several months.

They have three small dogs on the premises which fight amongst themselves, so having your own dog might be a problem.

Suggest maximum length of bigrig to be not much over 8 metres. No height restrictions unless you have to park down the back

NOTE - ignore check-in  May 6th, 2016 by vbernaud Iconpopout   and the bottom three photos - was for a different place

name: Il Giardino
description: Good restaurant with friendly staff. I had a burger for 6.50 usd and a large beer for 3.50 usd. Nice spot directly at the Charles Darwin promenade as well

name: Kaluz Hosteria And Spa
description: $10 each person per night for camping with full breakfast with coffee and homemade hot chocolate included.  Pool with wet bar and pool table.  Great chef named Diego who speaks perfect English. Free tours of botanical gardens, hot springs, and Cacao farm.  Just down the street from Shuar community hot springs.  Highly recommend.  Wifi included for free.

name: Runa Wasi
description:
Asked if we could camp behind this restaurant.  Flat gravel lot away from the road with nice view. 
Tienda sells beer and homemade yogurt and cheeses.

name: Galápagos Travelers Dive Center
description: Nice dive shop that offers tours with 2 dives per day. Not necessary to be certified. I've seen manta rays, sharks, seals and at least 100.000 different fish a must do while on the islands :) I paid 140 USD including photos, videos, snacks, transfer and boat ride. Allan is a cool and knowledgeable dive master. They do tours with 6 people

name: Cevicheria Saboreame
description: Great local food stall/restaurant. We had ceviche and pescado ecocado. 5 usd each. Big beer is 1.75 usd. Cool place (it's the one with the Orange sign and red and green letters, as there are too places called the same)

name: La Cosecha Coffee
description:
great coffee (Rio Intag Organic Arabic) and tasty food (bagels, sandwiches & fresh baked goods)

Located on Calle Modesto Jaramillo, between Pasaje Saona and Calle Salinas. facing the Plaza de los Ponchos.

name: Hosteria La Roulotte de Mindo
description: located 2km from the town centre (on the road leading to the Butterfly Farm). $5 pp/night in own car. You can also rent a unique "roulotte" (caravan) for $35 per person (with breakfast included). The restaurant is housed in a light and airy wooden building with wide panoramic windows that blends perfectly with the cloud forest that surrounds it. Enjoy a wood-oven pizza while you observe hummingbirds. clean bathroom in the restaurant. Shower in the house. They are building new showers for campers. Libardo is extremely friendly and helpful! Check out their website for pics!

name: Los Frailes - Beach
description: Nice Beach in the national parc. No entrance fee but parking is US$2. Showers and toilets available. You are not allowed to stay overnight. You have to follow the gravel road for 2.6 km from the main road to the beach parking. Beach is closed at 4 pm. You can leave bicycles in the parking lot. They weren't completely under guard, but we left them locked to a tree in the shade next to the ice cream vendors and felt safe.

name: La Virgen
description: Parking lot at the head to the trail to Los Illanizas. No infrastructure. Road leading to the parking lot is a little washed out at parts but we had no trouble. If it rains a lot, getting down can be dangerous. Beautiful views when weather is good.

name: Zumba
description:
This is the last fuel station en route to Peru. You can get as much fuel as you need at national price. We recommend filling up in Vilcabamba just to be sure if you want to pay the less expensive rate (fuel costs in Peru are reportedly MUCH higher than in Ecuador).

They will not accept USD $50 or $100 notes. Bank in town will change them (reluctantly)

name: masgas - Gas Station
description: For free, cold showers and toilets available, some restaurants close to the gas station.

name: Canoe Launch
description:
A beautiful riverside location that's used by the locals and the nearby river lodges as a pick-up and drop off site with canoes. Don Victor lives with his family on the house above and charges $2 for car parking but we camped down by the launch site (without blocking access) and didn't pay. You meet interesting people living, vacationing and volunteering in the vicinity. You can charter a boat here to a wild animal rescue park close by. 

For those interested in coming from or going to Coca up north, there exists a road (unmarked on paper and digital maps as of 2015) that follows the Amazon side of the Napo river. Only one third is paved but the rest is fairly graded with a few easy shallow river crossings. Nice drive, highly recommended.

name: Kerstin's Cul-de-Sac
description: Kirsten is a German ex-pat who has been living in Coca for about seven years. She speaks German, English and Spanish. She and her Quechua husband run a local tour company that can take you deep into the jungle on the Napo river. We camped on the lot right in front of their house for two days. We mentioned the lack of campgrounds in the city and they said they would happily offer this service for future travellers! The area is on the western edge of the town away from the crowd. For $10, you can camp in your rig with access to electricity and use the bathroom/shower in the house. It rains a lot and the streets are not paved so be prepared to deal with mud. There are quite a few harmless dogs around since most residents in the neighborhood have a few. All in all, this is a relatively quite and safe place to stay in Coca. And you can get all the information you need about exploring the Ecuadorean Amazon from this couple. Think of it as a home stay and you won't be disappointed. At the malecon, across the navi station there's her families' tour company. It's the last little shack on the right where the street ends.

name: Zumag Sisa (Hostal & Camping)
description:
A reasonably priced hostel with tall covered parking lot, private rooms and bathrooms. Very fast wifi!! Secure parking. There's a kitchen and public area as well. All for $10 pp for private room, private bath, or camping for $5 pp. Marcia and Pablo are the owners. Pablo also has a few off-road vehicles and is well informed about the region. 

The hostel has a large, breezy chill-out area on our terrace with hammocks and beautiful views over the city and the mountains in the distance. T hey offer spacious single and double rooms and dorms, all with private bathrooms and fans. They have a spacious kitchen, a barbecue area, two dining rooms, Wi-Fi and masive private parking. 

Just a short bus ride away from the hostel you can find lagoons and waterfalls, green rivers, visit the Quechua’s ethnic groups, or try rafting (Tena is considered one of the best rafting destinations in South America).Tena is a gathering point for tourists who want to enjoy the Amazon region of Ecuador. You can reachTena in only 3 hours by bus from Baños or in 4 hours from Quito.

name: Car Tech
description: Excellent mechanics. The manager, Rafael Segale, is very professional. They fit us in the next day to install a Jeep part (which we brought with us) and check our brakes. Address is Los Naranjos N44-600 at the corner of de las Azucenas. Tel: 3342-861. Email: cartech1@hotmail.com

name: Hostel La Rosario
description: Great deal. Hostel with a garage about 10 minutes walk to Old Town. Our Jeep is 2.3 meters high and we fit in the garage no problem. The entry is about 2.4 meters and there is space in the garage for 4-5 regular size cars. A room for 2 of us was $28 per night. Very clean, comfortable. Showers are hot with strong water pressure. Five wifi networks in the building so you can always find a strong signal. The staff is very helpful. There is a kitchen in the first floor off of the garage that is available for guests to use. Breakfast is not served here, but a great breakfast place is nearby, Frutería Monserate.

name: Cascada Pailón del Diablo
description: There are two ways to visit the waterfall, this one is the so-called ‘Ecuadorean’ side. This path is the best option to reach the waterfall. A good trail goes down to the entrance. Entrance costs $3 for adults and $2 for children aged 5 to 11. There you continue up on steps, to different balconies, halfway to the huge waterfall. At the opposite of the first balcony you can enter a small tunnel, that brings you to the side of the waterfall. Be prepared for a shower. Once back at the entrance, you go down and can cross a hanging bridge. From the other side the complete waterfall is visible. It’s amazing, worth the money! The other path makes you only to the top of the waterfall, where you cannot see the complete falls. Also there you cross hanging bridges, and go close to the falls. But there is no way down. It’s organised by another company, so if you want to do both, you pay twice.

name: Cotopaxi climbing guide
description: Gaspar Navarrete - +593 99 328 9418.   Or Pablo Silva +593 96 932 9488 or Pomo.pabloco.alvarez21@gmail.com.     Gaspar speaks great English and Pablo knows some. They helped get some gear that we were missing (crampons, ice axe and helmet.) They are incredibly professional, safe, nice and fun! We had a genuinely great time spending 5 days with them climbing. Would certainly recommend reaching out to them if you're planning on climbing anything in the area.

name: Hosteria Farallon Dillon
description: big and safe parking place . Usd 5 per person, good WiFi, pool has an extra cost, very good restaurant,laundry,110 volt, hot water in the showers

name: Chimborazo Climbing Guide
description: Gaspar Navarrete - +593 99 328 9418.   Or Pablo Silva +593 96 932 9488 or Pomo.pabloco.alvarez21@gmail.com.     Gaspar speaks great English and Pablo knows some. They helped get some gear that we were missing (crampons, ice axe and helmet.) They are incredibly professional, safe, nice and fun! We had a genuinely great time spending 5 days with them climbing. Would certainly recommend reaching out to them if you're planning on climbing anything in the area

name: Mama Ines Of Rio Blanco
description: Thinking it would be the only way to arrange a stay with a native Kechua family, we arranged a trip with the native-run tour company in Tena. But you don't need to do that. In fact, do not do that. It costs more than necessary. If you get here by your own means, sleep in your own rig and cook your own meals, you would only be paying for guided tours. Just drive to Rio Blanco, park in front of Mama Ines' tienda and ask for her or her son Hengry. There is electricity, flushing toilet, running water and a porch to sit but everything is very basic. Hengry told us that $10 to $15 is sufficient based on the daily time he spends guiding around. He also mentioned a $20 community fee but it sounded like that would be a one time payment. Be aware that the tienda has very simple provisions and they may not be able to provide food if you show up without notice. Rainforest hikes, river and waterfall swims, handcraft demonstrations, farming, trap building, local cooking and Shamanic ayahuasca ceremony are among the things you can experience. Make sure to leave your orientalist 'Amazonian native' illusions behind. You won't be seeing blowpipe hunters walking around butt-naked. Your perceptions of authenticity will probably have to change a bit.

name: Hosteria Hacienda San Joaquin Cotopaxi
description:
$7.50 per person. great place to stay off the PanAm (@ exit Parque Nacional Cotopaxi) and to acclimatize for Cotopaxi National Park. very clean washrooms & hot showers. Could use kitchen to wash dishes. cozy room with fire place with great wifi. very friendly owner and staff. lots of friendly dogs around. 

Servicios:
- Hospedaje
- Restaurante cafeteria
- Chimenea
- Wi-fi
- Zona de Camping
- Caminata
- Servicios sanitarios para campistas
- Lavanderia
- Información turística
- Parqueadero

name: Hosteria El Chorro
description: Nice place to stop if you are going thowards guayaquil. Hosteria with a couple of swiming pools and a waterfall. The owner is really nice. 10$/night incl. private shower/bathroom

name: Arie's cabins
description: Arie is a very friendly and absolutely helpful Dutch guy. He offers camping for up to three caravans (not too big ones) in front of his cabanas. Wifi, electricity, showers (in cabana) are available. 8 USD/car, same price for only parking. He also has a washing machine - 3 USD/fill. Close to Quito airport, so it is a good and safe spot to park the car for a Galapagos week. He offers the transport to and pickup at the airport as well (15 USD) - for us he had to wait for two hours because of a delayed arrival! Big rigs might get parked on the neighbors ground. Enter a small side road on the right sight coming from Quito at S 0.214083 W 78.360136.

name: Multimarcas R.B.R. Mecanica RAPIDA
description: We had a very good service at this garage. We had a problem with the brakes of our Dodge Campervan. Those parts are impossible to find in Ecuador. Ricardo the owner and his team are very ingenious; they rebuild our brakes pads. They fix the problem the same day and the cost was very good. They are sympathetic and very helpful. They only speak spanish. They are doing any kind of mechanical. We highly recommend that place near Quito.

name: parking in front of kids game area
description: a cool parking in front of à kid park. free. Water possible. guards are really friendly.

name: Dentist Dr Jorge A Jimenez
description: Really nice dentist. We got a teeth cleaning done here. Costs around $15-30. Walk ins only. Open till 7pm during the week.

name: Samvara
description: Nice place to come after we were rejected from Punta Prieta. Really nice pool, restaurant, bathrooms, showers, beach access, no wifi currently. $10 pp to camp or $24 for a bed and private bath.

name: Mindo - Hacienda San Vicente
description: Nice quiet place in a wonderful garden, center in walking distance, nature trails& nature pool. Very clean shower, water, electricity, common room, WiFi, 8$p.P

name: Airport in Catamayo
description: Quiet and secure overnight place in front of the airport, 2 km south of town

name: Mirador Crater Pululahua
description: We could stay in the secured garden from a little restaurant , just a few meters down on the left hand side from the park entrance, 3$ night,

name: Sole Mare Hostal
description: Great spot on the beach. 20pp including breakfast. Very clean and safe covered moto parking. Owners are very cool and on it.

name: parking in the street near river
description:
a quiet park place on the street near the river . north entrance of cuenca
wi fi gratis Buenos para mirar una pelicula

name: Aqua Center Sinchi Misahualli
description: A beautiful Jungle Lodge with Restaurant, nice garden, short trails, cold shower and clean restrooms, 5$ per night

name: Banana Lodge
description:
The lodge offers camping also. In a lovely garden, close to the Rio Misahualli, where you can sit on a terrace over the river and enjoy your beer. Hot showers, WiFi for 4 USD per person
NOTE for bigrigs - maximum height is 3.4 metres under gate

name: Panamericana between Ambuquil and Ibarra
description: A new condominio with cabanas, pool, palapa, barbecue. We were allowed to use one of the bathrooms in a cabin. Hot shower, very clean toilets.  There is a possibility to do laundry with the washing machine of the nice owners. A bit noisy because of the Panamericana.  Good base for day trips to the hot springs of Chachimbiro (N 0.46009 W 78.23303, 2,456 m), the Reserva Ecologica El Angel (park entrance: N 0.70371 W 77.96734, 3,400m / Refugio: N 0.73821 W 78.02750, 3,900m - from there great 3, 5K hike to a Mirador) and the thermal hot springs and the cave of La Paz (0.49902 N 77.84350 W).  (US $ 5 / person)

name: Farm "Piemonte"
description: We asked at a private farm and were allowed to camp overnight in the yard.  From the farm a pretty rough road starts up to the Refugio of Cayambe. When we were there it was raining and snowing. The slope was partly extremely muddy. 2.5 kilometers (over 4,300 meters above sea level) before the Refugio we turned back as we didn't want to take the risk driving the steep switchback of the last kilometers.

name: Restaurant Sabor Bamboo "Beim Mayer"
description: The East Berlin Original "Mayer" runs a restaurant / pub at the end of the beach. You can park your car at the side of the road and camp there or rent Cabana. We were allowed to use the toilet and cold shower of Cabana. At Mayer's, there is a real yummy pizza and entertainment ("Vaste de wat ick mene, oda?")

name: Cabañas Irunia
description: Fantastic campground under coconut trees directly at the long sandy beach. Toilets and cold showers. We have been the first guests for the very nice owner Teresa. The small area is only accessible at low tide, because you have to drive north along the beach about a mile from Mompiche. Since the spot is limited in space it is only suitable for vehicles up to six meters length.  You should not miss dinner with Teresa. Fresh seafood, cooked to perfection - just a dream !!! (10 US $ / person)  (4 US $ / person)

name: Hosteria Ecologica Nicanchigua
description: We stayed on the small parking lot in front of the restaurant. Hot showers and clean toilets in the cabins. Very nice garden with chairs at the river. In 10 minutes walking distance you reach Mindo.  (US $ 5 / person)

name: Pululahua Hostal
description: Camping in the parking lot next to the hostel. Hot showers, clean toilets. Free WIFI. Great views. Excellent base for hikes in the crater area.  Do not miss the detour to the view point on the crater (N 78.48256 W 0.02426).  (3 US $ / person)

name: Hosteria Papagayo
description: You can park in the (small) parking lot in front of the hostel. Hot showers, toilets. Free WIFI. Common area in the hostel. Beautiful view of the Rumiñahui.  (Originally US $ 6 / person., After hearing only $ 4 / pers.)

name: Hostal Terra
description: 500m from the airport, next to the main road. Sorrounded by high walls and gates.  Take the black gate on the right. We torned down the alarm wire from the wall completely when driving through the left gate!  $ 15 is the price for a double room. Therefore, one should insist on getting his own room key. Very clean bathroom with hot shower and even soap and towels. Free WIFI.

name: Finca Chamanapamba Regines Café Aleman
description: A designer dream based on Hundertwasser and Gaudi? made true by the two Germans Regine and Dietrich. Stunning property with a small gem hotel and restaurant. We had coffee and dinner there and were therefore allowed to stay in the parking lot. Clean toilets and hot water jungle shower. Short trail to the waterfall Chamanapamba.

name: Side street in the city center
description: We didn't find anything suitable for the night, and finally parked on a road in a slightly better looking residential area. Quiet night.  Caution: Alausi is built on a hillside and therefore has narrow and partially brutally steep roads.

name: Hostería Paraíso
description: We arrived in pouring rain and in thick fog at the Hosteria and parked our vehicle in the large car park. At dusk, someone came by and asked what we were doing here. As we asked if we could camp for the night in the parking lot this was agreed without any problems.  In the gold mining town of Zaruma. Better park the car outside of the historic center as there are very narrow and steep roads.

name: Bosque Petrificado de Puyango
description:
Along the river, about 1 km from the entrance of the park. The facility is brand new, the bathrooms were not yet in operation. Cold shower and clean toilets at the visitor center (400 m). Bird observation tower, benches and tables. Very helpful and caring employees.  The admission to the Petrified Forest costs an additional US $ 1 / person. Great hikes on boardwalks in the park. We were the only guests and received the key to the park gate from the Ranger.  (3 US $ / person)

bosque petrificado official campground, ask the rangers at the bosque petrificado for permission. 3$/p, cold showers (little pressure), electricity, big area with tables and raincover, wifi. Overlooking the river. Look for a brown gate on the right. There is no sign and it doesnt look like a camping unless you go down to the house. Steep and a bit rocky to get down.

name: Hosteria Campo Alegre
description:
You can stay at the parking lot of the hosteria. Hot showers and WiFi available. Good place when passing through. 2 USD per person.
$ 20 per person (2020)
Had our dog here and they didn't care of him.

name: Hostal Terra 3
description: You can safely stay at the parking lot of the hotel. Take the first door when coming from north. We had to take a room, but it was cheap. Only 19 USD. However therer is a lot of "traffic" because most people are only staying for some hours.Esta bien ubicado cerca de centros comerciales y facilidades de transporte

name: Hotel La Mision
description:
You can stay at the small lot left of the entrance (not the parking lot!). But take care of all belongings. A pair of sneakers are stolen - and only an employee of the hotel could be the thief.
And with 16.80 USD per night it is overpriced

Better try next door. Hostel Oasis

name: By the riverside
description: Parking at a good distance from the road, but not hidden . There's a river which has been dammed a bit, for the kids to swim in. Was pretty quiet when we were there though.

name: Policia national Ecuador
description: We couldn't fit in the hotel parking.  Parked Free on the street outside police station

name: Campsite Mitad Del Mundo
description:
It is a campground of a local farmer's family. The place is beautiful, very quiet, safe, lot of space and you camp on flat grass. The owner is called Valentin and is the father of the local guide of the monument of the center of the world in Cayambe. He has a nursery and a garden with all kinds of organic vegetables, if you want you can buy some lettuce, etc from him. The price is 10usd per vehicle. To get here:
- follow the signs of "casa de los venados". (They will probably put up new signs for the campsite), 
- before the casa de los venados, after a swimming pool with a blue roof, go to the first house on the left. 300mt from the panamericana.
Water and bathrooms, and electricity. Help the locals!

name: Sinchi Warmi
description:
Really lovely lodge with beautiful gardens, chill out areas and hammocks and fast WiFi, $5 per person to camp.

This is a lodge of a local Community of woman in the middle of the jungle in a really beatiful location. There are bathrooms and showers. You can take tours with them, we took 3 activities that I would really recommend. They thought us how to make chocolate and local crafts and we also got a tour into the jungle, were they thought us about all the medicine plants and the animals (everything with really reasonable prices).We really enjoy and recommend this place. USD 10 per night. 
Once you get to Misahualli,cross the bridge and then 1 km to the left you will find this lodge. They also have a restaurant, but we did not try. Help the locals!
The bridge from Misahualli to the lodge has a barrier at 2.50m high.

name: Hosteria Luzcelinda
description: Hosteria.  They've never had campers before, but were happy to put us up in an open area they have behind the place, down a dirt road near a small pond.  Access to pool, bar, restaurant, showers, bathrooms.  $10pp/night.

name: Llanta Matic
description: Great place to fix tires or buy new ones.

name: Casabaca Toyota
description: Professional dealership, some reception staff speak English as well as Freddy one of the head mechanics. Prices reasonable. Good wifi is a bonus.

name: CEBAF Peru-Ecuador border
description:
Both countries have offices in this complex. Stop here if Exiting Peru and Entering Ecuador & if exiting Ecuador and Entering Peru. 

Ecuador Aduana is open 08:00 to 19:00 weekdays and 08:00 to 13:00 Saturdays.  If you arrive when closed you will need to go down the road to the Aduana Control about 6km, also on iOverlander.  

Note: offices on the Peru side close at 5pm. 
Peruvian aduana is 24 hours Monday to Sunday, there is a sign at the aduana window and the officer confirmed it.

name: Autoservicio Alvarado
description:
Great mechanic. Very friendly and good
 value. Make us many controls.

name: Star Motors
description: A big Mercedes, MAN and VW Garage, we did some repair and could stay overnight

name: Refugio De Las Aves
description: Beautiful eco lodge, bambus houses, very relaxed. Price depends on the deal you make with the owner...

name: Sol Y Luna
description: 15$ / room per per night, very nice and very friendly, very quite but now is the low season.. We heard camping at the beach is not that riskfree anymore so we opted for this.

name: Dentist
description: A very good empathic Dentist, speaks excellent English, reasonable price, modern equipment. Isabel Galarza email:cuencadentist@gmail.com

name: River Guasuntos
description: A big leveled space near the riverbed. very nice both for RVs and for tents. Highly recommended.

name: Garage Khumo
description: Big gravel leveld fenced place. Cost is 5us$ per car or truck. (He asked for 5 at night and 5 per day...we agreed on 5 for both day and night) Ask in the guesthouse opposite side -magic stone- for the wifi password, very friendly Danish people. Approximately 3minutes from the center of the city.

name: Welding
description: If you need welding done, this is the place. Behind the bright green gate.  If you need a mechanic, head over a few blocks to the other noted place in iOverlander. Super nice and helpful mechanic. He directed us here for welding work.

name: Hostal Monte Carmelo
description:
One of the best places I've stayed at on my South America trip. Paid $18 for really nice double room. Good security for  bike/car etc. It's run by a lovely couple Marcela and Mario who were super helpful and friendly! Marcela speaks good english.

The included breakfast was nice, eggs, wonderful bread, fresh juices and coffee. Beer, Sodas, chocolate etc are all available at VERY good rates on an honour system. They'll make you really nice hotdogs for a dinner snack if you ask.

The shower is fantastic (lots of hot water and good pressure) Short 15 min walk into town center. Wished I could've stayed for longer

name: Hotel Lesly Salome
description: Hotel with big secure lot that should accommodate even large rigs. Cold shower in same space as toilet, intermittent WiFi. 15USD (for a matrimonial room, 2 persons & 1 camper).

name: *Closed* Hanging Bridge
description:
UPDATE:
You can cross here on foot by a basket hanging from a cable. Looks fairly safe and is free.

Currently closed. A cable snapped and as of 1/27/22 hasn’t been repaired in over a year, so don’t hold your breath. Bridge holds 10 Ton. Height restriction 2.5m as there are height bars installed 2017. You can access town from Tena side of river no problem.

name: Wilsons Vasco Parking
description: It is a Parking lot facing the river, beside the bridge. There is shower and toilet from the mercado. 20mtrs. Wifi from the guesthouse. The owner (lived in the U.S.) ex. Jungle guide... Knows a lot and is really nice and helpful. 80mtrs. To town. Price is about 2us$

name: Coco
description: 20 dollars for two nights. Beautiful huts. Very nice owner. Loads of parking. Wifi. Right on the beach! Nicest place we've stayed in!

name: Monte Lebano Hostal
description: Located at south end of road that runs along beach in Puerto Lopez. $5pp to park outside. Use of all facilities listed under amenities, including hammock chill out zone across road.

name: Hacienda La Condessa
description: they let us stay on the nice parking lot of the hotel, price: 5$ / night. we decided to eat in the hotel. basic but good meal. there is a very clean toilet outside. slow wifi at the reception.

name: Playa Rosada Carpark
description: ADMIN NOTE: This is a turtle breeding ground, NO camping of any kind is allowed.

name: Playa Rosada Carpark
description: Drove a few km off coastal highway to this beach, was deserted midweek. Beach really nice and quiet. Asked guy at restaurant about camping and he just kept saying "tranquilo, no pasa nada" and didn't want any money for camping, or for our using beach palapas. The guy sleeps on site, and opened banos (with showers) when needed. The carpark is huge and gates closed at night. Tranquilo, FREE.

name: Hosteria Mar Y Paz
description: Nice ecolodge with cabanas. Camped between the cabanas under trees. Quiet beach across the street. Very friendly owners Jaime and Catalina (speeks English very well). We payed 15 USD for 2 persons for a cabana with private bathroom and power for the car, but slept in the car. Very good WiFi and quiet at night.

name: Centro de Tourismo Shalala
description: Relatively new (2014) community Cabanas & Camping. Very nice setup 150 meter from the Lagua Quilotoa away. Good starting point for a hike around the lake. There is a mirador at the lake rim. Camping in walk in camping area or with a RV in the parking area. Very quite place. Extremely friendly stuff. We paid the 2 USD Entrance Fee pP and could camp without extra fee in our RV. Clean Restrooms and Showers next to the camping & parking area. Place can be reached via a 7km long very good gravel road. Big sign 1 km before reaching the lake on the road from Zumbahua.

name: Jardin Suizo - Hosteria & Camping
description:
Attention for all campers: From now on the entrance gate is 4.40m high, so even the biggest vans can enter the camping now.
.....
My name is Samuel Haerri and I am from Switzerland. I speak German, English and Spanish. Here in Puerto Cayo, I own a hosteria and Camping for Caravan and tents. I have a huge garden with over 200 different plants.
The quiet beach with opportunities to surf is just across the street and in the backyard on a small hill there is a great viewpoint to watch the sunset.
The property has a fence all around it, so it's always safe. I guarantee warm and cold showers and toilets. If you want, you can use my big kitchen to cook. Power with V110 and V220 is available at my place. If you want to do laundry I have a place on the rooftop to wash it by hand or my neighbor will wash it for you in her machine. Good working WiFi is available.

My prices:
Caravan - 6US per person
Tent - 6US per person
Kids from 0 to 6 years are free, from 6 to 12 pay half the price

If you are interested I will prepare a huge breakfast for you. The price is 6US.

I am looking forward to welcoming you at my place. For any more information, you can call me on 0980130373 or look on my website www.jardin-suizo.com.

name: Beach at Las Peñas infront of Restaurante "La Ramada"
description: A good reccomendation of Hans from Finca Summerwind. On the beach side of Restaurante "La Enramada" there is a nice area with a lawn and we were allowed to camp right next to it. You will recognize restaurante La Enramada by it's neat looking dryy tree brenches walls. There are a lot of public toillets in the main street, and a couple of wifi networks. The best is to ask for Mr. Giovanny, the owner of the restaurant, and he will gladly show you exactly were to camp. The beach was nice enough and food was relatively unexpensive. With a "colaboración" you can plug to the restaurant electricity.

name: Mompiche's Malecon infront of La Casa
description: MODERATOR NOTE: Place removed because camping is illegal here.  Private Property

name: Beach at Las Nuñez
description: After being kicked out Olon, and not being too enthusiatic about Montañita's night life we drove back and we found this peacefull and friendly place to camp, there was a sort of empty ground in which we camped right next to the beach and next to small shop in which we were allowed to use toillets (inside their house) Free

name: Camping at the beach in Montañita
description: A good recommendation by Adrian and Silvana a couple of argentians who searched for a way to make it to the beach in Montañita and they found it. At the end of the southern parking lot you'll see a dirt road leading to the beach that hasn't been closed, it takes you right into the beach with a couple of small trees near by. All services are in a five minutes walk to montañita. Free

name: Wild camping in empty ground at Puerto Engabao
description: If you surf this a great spot, the beach is nice and the village has a frenetic fishing activity. We were allowed to camp in a empty grount next to two vacation houses, the house keeper allowed us to use water from a pipe in the yard of the two houses. We loved it here,really peacefull place. Restrooms and Wifi in nearby small restaurants. Is also possible to camp next to the kiosks of the beach, just ask which one is not working and people will gladly inform you.

name: In front of the Fire station Guayaquil's city centre
description: We slept infront of the station in Av. 9 de Octubre, we were not invited by the fire-fighters to stay in since the have a very limited spaced, but we were able to park right in front of them and also spoke with two guards of one the buildings who encouraged us to stay telling us that it was a safe are and that nothing would happen. So it was, we spent a quite evening there and next morning we gave a 2 USD tip to the guards who were really happy about it. Lot's of shops and cafeterias were you can use toilets and get free internet.

name: Talleres ARS
description: Great mechanic, very professional and knowledgeable venezuelan Andres Rolando, the owner of the place is an avid 4x4 driver and loves overlanding, so you will feel like home here, they did a great job in the maintenance of our front tranny and of our back suspension that had a broken blade. We camped here for three nights and got some nice tours of Guayaquil while searching for spare parts. Definitively recommended!

name: Represa
description: A nice man made Lake, parking lot, round the corner a local restaurant. Very friendly locals. Free of charge. The bridge leading here from the east is without limits in size or weight.

name: La Posada del Abuelo (Hostel/Camping Sabina)
description: We was the first overlanders in the place. The owners are very friendly and very interested in receive other overlanders. We talked to then about this and the prices are USD 3 pp for camping with hot shower, Wi-Fi. Located near the Cascada La Virgen. Nice and quiet place to stay some days. For those ho want the address: Calle Juan Montalvo y Rafael Vieira.

name: Hosteria Alemana
description: Reception is inside restaurant. We got here on a Monday and pool, sauna etc were closed - only open on weekends. Price is now $7.5pp. Access to bathrooms (with TP & seats), hot showers. Internet that did not connect consistently where we parked. Parking is on a lot beside the hostel with foot access thru a door they left open all night. 110/220 power hookup just inside that door. Gate to parking is kept locked so access is thru hostel/ restaurant property only. No height restriction. Claro was 4G and very good.

name: Hosteria Miramelindo
description:
At Rio Verde
We camped on a parqueadero in front of the hosteria and had supper. Very good cuisine.
They let us use the WC,  shower and Wi-Fi.
Close to the ''Pailon Del Diallo'' waterfall, 10 min walk.

name: Villa San Marcos
description: $35 plus tax, total $43 for double with breakfast and very secure motorcycle parking. Parking would fit other vehicles too and is locked secure at night. Nice place in center. Banks and restaurants nearby. Good internet.

name: Bosch Workshop
description:
This place has a professional setup and equipment for car washes, oil changes, alignment and more serious work.

We stopped here for help to change our brake pads out. Turns out two of our front calipers were jammed. The mechanic that owns this place helped take apart our calipers, bang them loose and sand/polish them into submission. Rebuilt calipers installed with new brakes sent us on our way in 4 hours. All this for ~US$50.

While our car was being worked on we spoke to a local car parts salesmen that used to live/work in Florida. He lives 2 hours away and brings his car here for work. Swears he's the best mechanic in Ecuador. 

We highly recommend this guy if you've got some work, (routine or not) to be done.

name: Dead end of a town road
description: Free and almost In the bush, nice neighbors.

name: Hostal Paredes
description: Basic hostel, friendly owner, hot water, wifi, double room with bathroom for $15 for the room, breakfast available at $3,50, in walking distance from the city center, possible to sqeeze two or three motorbikes in the patio. phone number 0968221822 / 2835674

name: Hostal San Luis
description: Basic hostel in the city center, double room with private bathroom for $10 per person for the room, hot water, towels and soap, wifi, safe parking (not for big rigs), breakfast not included.

name: Hostal Real Colon
description: Nice hostel, modern, clean, double room with private bathroom for $30 for the room, hot water, towels, wifi, secure parking, breakfast included (but very bad)

name: Wild Camping up the hills near Hotel San Jose De Sighos
description: Near the hotel is a track up the hills to places with an amazing view. The hotel has a key to the gate that is locked with a chain. From the top of the hill you overlook many miles of mountains, valleys, volcanos. Absolute silence during the night (when the dogs and disco in the valley have finally shut up). You need a 4x4 to drive up the steep track, especially wfhen it rains. You need to pay something to the hotel and you can agree to use their restaurant and facilities, like wifi, bathroom and swimming pool. We paid Usd 20. If you want to, check it out first on horseback. Horses can be hired through hotel reception. The hotel is on Tripadvisor.

name: Roadside.Thermales San Luis De Guachala
description: Next to the hot pools (entrance 1$ / 50cts  )and the river, calm and free. Restaurant and little playground. Opens 8h-16h.

name: Hostal Tiana
description: Very nice hostel with cafe in the garden. Rooms and bathrooms are really clean and staff is very friendly. You can book tours within the hostel. Breakfast included. We paid 10.50$ per person per night for a 4 bed dorm. The hostel itself has no parking but there is a private parking next door for 4$ per night. Location itself is great. The main square is just around the corner. Recommendable if you want to stay in Latacunga

name: Comreivic Iveco
description: Official Iveco.... Same company than in Quito. Was helpful and we could leave our truck here for 2 weeks to visit Galapagos !

name: Hotel Las Canaris
description: Was gunning for Cuenca from Quito, didn't make it, and landed in this awesome hotel instead. $15 for a single private room with bathroom, seriously hot shower, comfortable bed and fast wifi. Restaurant right next door. Secure covered parking for cars and bikes included (driveway is narrow so bigger vehicles might have trouble). Great random place to stop for the night if you're heading south.

name: Gas Station PS7
description: Almost quiet... At the rear next to the building, flat area. Little playground for kids and mini market. Nice for transit.

name: Parquadero Aeroporto Guayaquil
description: You can park and sleep in your car on the parking lot of the airport. Ticket for 24 hours is $14,40. Toilets in the Airport Building, free WiFi for 30 Minutes.

name: Parking South End of Montañita
description: Nice and quiet parking lot directly on the nice beach of Montañita. Just a few minutes into town, where you find all amendities. maybe it will be crowded and noisy during weekends, free!

name: Hosteria Safari
description: We had to stop here after sunset because our headlights were broken. We paid 35pp for a double room including dinner and breakfast. It's just too much since the rooms are really basic and kind of dirty. There is a swimming pool, hammocks and pool tables but still not worth the money. Would not recommend that place.

name: Hostel Mallki
description: Hostel on quieter side of town. Very friendly staff, we'll run.

name: Cabana Rio Napo
description: Great cabanas on tranquil property. We paid $20 each per night for a full cabana, includes a big breakfast and friendly staff. Wifi in the restaurant- average. Two decks overlooking the river and bridge, with hammocks- didn't want to leave. Parking next to reception- gates locked at night and road is quiet.

name: Fuera De Babilonia
description: Great pizza and food. Pizza is about $12 and a local meal about $7. Worth the price - real wood fired pizza and the family who run the place are great. Good wifi!

name: Vuelo Del Condor
description:
Swing in the air above a canyon! 

Balançoire dans le vide au dessus d'un canyon ! Possible de rester dormir.

name: La Paz ES
